Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story:
I glanced at the clock, my heart pounding. Only two hours left before the polls closed, and I still hadn’t voted. I’d promised myself I wouldn’t miss this election, not after all the debates and discussions. But as I grabbed my keys, I heard the front door open. My boyfriend walked in, shoulders slumped, eyes red. He barely managed a weak smile before collapsing onto the couch. “It was awful,” he muttered, voice cracking. “My boss said my project wasn’t good enough. I don’t know what to do.”

I sat beside him, torn. He needed me—needed comfort, reassurance, someone to listen. That’s what a good girlfriend does, right? But the minutes ticked by, and the weight of my civic duty pressed on me. If I left now, I’d be abandoning him when he was at his lowest. If I stayed, I might miss my chance to vote, something I’d been looking forward to for weeks. My chest tightened as I tried to decide which role I owed more to in this moment, feeling the impossible pull of both.
